column1: Suizhou (simplified Chinese: 随州; traditional Chinese: 隨州; pinyin: Suízhōu)
column2: formerly Sui County (simplified Chinese: 随县; traditional Chinese: 隨縣; pinyin: Suí Xian
column4: is a prefecture-level city in northern Hubei province
column6: bordering Henan province to the north and east.

column1: The Sui in Suizhou is derived from the ancient 'Suishizu' (随氏族) .
The prefecture-level city of Suizhou administers 5 county-level divisions
Suizhou Economic Development Area (随州经济开发区)
Dahongshan Scenic Area (随州大洪山风景名胜区)These are further divided into 54 township-level divisions
Suizhou has a long history. During the Spring and Autumn Period and Warring States Period (771−221 BCE)
column2: it was the territory of the State of Sui/Zeng and within the cultural sphere of the State of Chu. As a prefecture-level city Suizhou has a short history with its current status only granted by the State Council in June 2000.

column1: The Catholic minority is pastorally served by its own (dormant?) pre-diocesan Apostolic Prefecture of Suixian (隨縣) which is exempt
column2: i.e. directly dependent on the Holy See (and its missionary Roman Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples)
column3: not part of any ecclesiastical province.

column1: It was established on 1937.06.17 as Apostolic Prefecture of Suixian (隨縣) / Suihsien / Suihsienen(sis) (Latin adjective)
column2: on territory split off from the Apostolic Vicariate of Hankou (漢口).

column3: having had only the following incumbents :

column1: Apostolic Administrator Friar Dominic Chen Te-mien
Suizhou is served by the Hankou–Danjiangkou Railway.
